title: Materiales Vallejo
caption: Designing and developing a building material store’s first website.

subsections.text: Late January 2016 my father was approached by an advertising agency offering to create Materiales Vallejo’s first website. My father knew I was interested in learning more about web design and development and asked if I wanted to take care of the family business website. He offered full creative freedom and availability for business research and content details. At the time I had experience working with website builders and a basic understanding of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. I accepted the offer and saw it as the perfect opportunity to learn more about the web while helping my family’s business in a small way.

While my father came up with a list of products and services, I searched online for the websites I liked the most and started exploring with different website layouts. Simultaneously, I worked on establishing a visual direction for the site—I explored with colors, spacing, and icons— and drove to my hometown for a weekend to take product and store pictures.

After a month of exploring with different layouts and visual directions, I finally found a design I was happy with. My father approved of the design and content and I started figuring out how to develop the website.

I worked for a month and a half to develop the website. Along the way I used git for the first time, learned about CSS and SASS, and took innumerable Treehouse courses to catch up on HTML and learn about JavaScript. I published the website and continued working on other web projects and taking web development courses online.

A month passed and I got an opportunity to critique my father’s website. I realized there was superfluous content and too many images and as a consequence the experience was slow and fragmented. So I decided to redesign and rebuild the website to offer a faster, simpler experience.

The website was published and I got busy with other web projects while I continued to learn more about web design and development. Five months passed and I got a chance to critique my father’s website again. I realized I had been designing for visuals and had no business or user problems I was trying to solve. On top of that, the website had several layout flaws and IE bugs that I had to fix. So I decided to redesign and redevelop the website, but this time I defined a purpose and designed for particular business and user needs.

Materiales Vallejo is a small building material store in Matamoros, Tamaulipas selling cement, steel bars, and other building materials to local clients. The business is part of a community in Mexico where online retail is inexistent and where establishing an online presence is not even contemplated.

The website was designed to engage with local potential customers and to expedite the hiring process. At the same time, since Materiales Vallejo has no budget or time to manage the website, hosting should be free and development tools should make content editing simple and fast.

Any potential client that calls the business looks for three things: product availability, price, and delivery estimates. 70% of business revenue comes from wholeselling to local material and hardware stores. In Mexico, particularly in wholeselling, pricing is kept private. Every client gets a different price based on length of relationship with the business, frequency of purchase, and volume of purchase. As a consequence, clients have to interact with the business to figure out pricing.

The website was designed to provide a quick run-through of the business while providing accessible and up-to-date forms of contact. The website was designed for construction firm secretaries and small business owners that have purchasing power and that are familiar with building material use and terminology and that are used to calling the business to find out about product pricing.

The business has 16 employees and has a very out-of-date hiring process. Whenever there’s an available job, the business publishes a job ad in a local newspaper and on several radio stations. Anyone who’s interested in applying has to go to an office supply store, purchase a job application form, and deliver the application in person or via email.

The website will help automate the job application process by featuring a jobs section, where potential new hires can obtain information about the available job and fill out a form to apply online, saving applicants time and money. At the same time, the applications will be sent to a private site where the business will have an easier way to manage and navigate through job applications.

Core users should know who the business is and what it offers on their first impression of the website. The index page was designed to provide a quick but complete snapshot of the business and contains all the information the core user looks for. Each section was structured to provide efficient content consumption while minimizing section height to keep the experience short.

Core users should be able to find available products as fast as possible. Product cards were ordered from most popular to least popular and were arranged by category. Product cards were designed to provide just enough information for users to navigate through the carrusel without having to process product details. If the user is interested in learning more about the product, the user can press the product card and read about available measurements and sale unit.

Core users should be able to contact the business at any point of their experience. The site features auto-updating forms of contact that prioritize user engagement. If the business is open, contact buttons and relevant content sections invite the user to call the office. Otherwise, contact buttons and content invite the user to send an email.

The business should be able to share a link to a job detail page in the newspaper and radio ads so potential hires can find more about eh job and fill out an online application. At the same time, the website should display a job banner that doesn’t interfere with the core user experience.
